etymologies: early 19th century (as a noun): from modern Latin invertebrata (plural) ‘the invertebrates’ (former taxonomic group), from French invertébrés, from in- ‘without’ + Latin vertebra (see vertebra)

definitions: an animal lacking a backbone, such as an arthropod, mollusc, annelid, coelenterate, etc. The invertebrates constitute an artificial division of the animal kingdom, comprising 95 per cent of animal species and about thirty different phyla.
shortDefinitions: animal lacking backbone, such as arthropod

definitions: denoting an invertebrate or relating to the invertebrates as a group.
shortDefinitions: relating to or belonging to the invertebrates

examples.text: so invertebrate is today's Congress regarding foreign policy responsibilities
